papers.title: Helping Children Cope with Divorce, Death, and Deployment
papers.abstract: During the past decade, pediatricians have increasingly incorporated the social-ecological model of health into their practices, recognizing the profound interactions between environmental and individual factors in child health outcomes. Despite a growing awareness of the social determinants of health, comparatively little attention has been given to the impact of a child being separated from a parent, despite the fact that more than 1 million American children experience divorce, death of a parent, or deployment of a parent each year.Although divorce, parental death, and deployment arise from dramatically different family circumstances, each of these events can have lasting effects on involved children. For pediatricians, routine health supervision visits should include surveillance of stressors associated with either a current or impending separation, as well as the social and familial changes that can occur before, during, and after such experiences. When assessing a child undergoing a temporary or permanent separation from a parent, a pediatrician should be aware of the health risks experienced by the child, as well as being prepared to offer an appropriate palette of options for support to the child and caregiver(s).Special attention should be given to a patient’s developmental stage because children of different ages will present with sequelae of varying types and severities. For example, developing secure attachment to caregivers is an important feature of infancy and early childhood; thus, a change in a child’s day-to-day routine or the presence or absence of particular caregivers may result in increased fussiness or irritability, regression of developmental milestones, or disturbance in sleep and feeding patterns. As children mature, their understanding of parent separation likewise evolves. For example, in the context of divorce, older children will have an increasing understanding of the permanence of divorce as well as the abstract and complex issues involved. For adolescents, increased risk-taking behavior, poor school performance, depression, or anxiety can be associated with all types of parent separation.Beyond developmental factors, family and social risk factors are also relevant. In the case of the bereaved child, the preceding levels of family cohesion are strong predictors of behavioral and emotional symptoms after a parent’s death. With divorce, children with an easy-going temperament and average or higher cognitive abilities are better able to seek out support and adapt to change. When a parent is deployed, the nondeployed parent’s ability to engage his or her own support systems influences the child’s own behavior and coping. Conversely, numerous negative risk factors increase the possibility of poor health and behavior outcomes. For example, any parent separation can exacerbate financial difficulties and the ability of a remaining parent to find adequate child care. A child may encounter disrupted family or community supports and experience maladaptive parenting behaviors due to the caregiver’s own mental health needs, which may or may not be related to the separation. In addition, health-care providers should be alert to the risk of neglect and abuse, which are increased in the period during and after a military deployment.The behavior changes associated with divorce or death generally last for 6 to 12 months, followed by a return to the child’s previous function by 2 to 3 years. However, somatic (nonspecific complaints such as stomachaches or headaches) and behavioral (includes problems with school, attention, mood, anger, sleep, eating disorders, or substance abuse) symptoms can persist or return in the context of special days such as birthdays or holidays or with additional stressors such as family conflict or new living situations. In addition, divorce and death can result in long-term sequelae related to difficulty with long-term relationships (both as an adolescent and later as an adult), an increased risk of suicide, and persistent academic and behavioral problems. However, although there are many similarities in the way that a child responds to the absence of a parent, the social particularities of each type of separation can also result in differences in long-term behaviors and well-being.Divorce can be a dynamic process, introducing new conflicts and transitions as the relationships between parents and children evolve, such as the introduction of a stepparent or changes in school or home environments. The presence of parental conflict can be a particularly detrimental factor compounding the stress of these transitions. Witnessing conflict exposes children to toxic stress, and persistent negativity between parents can disrupt parental attachment, forcing children to feel the need to take one parent’s side over the other. In addition, because children are often caught in the middle, they can experience increased anxiety related to blaming themselves for the separation and feeling burdened with facilitating their parents’ reunification.In contrast to the often unpredictable chronology of divorce, the stresses of deployment tend to be concentrated at discrete points, most commonly times of deployment and reintegration. Of the more than 1 million service members with children who have been deployed to Iraq and Afghanistan, 48% of them served 2 or more deployments, with the average deployment lasting 7.7 months. The deployments were followed by a 3- to 6-month period of reintegration, where 44% of service members reported readjustment difficulties, with similar percentages describing strains on family life (48%), outbursts of anger (47%), and posttraumatic stress (49%). Much of the stress around reintegration is related to adjustment to the changing familial roles that arise during a deployment as well as the developmental transitions that a family member may have missed while deployed, such as infants who have developed new tantrums or increased independence while the parent was away. Younger adolescents seem to have the most difficulty with reintegration because they may be required to relinquish authority and responsibility that they had assumed in their family during the absence of the deployed parent.Children experiencing the death of a family member can move through predictable stages of grief that can vary in length according to the developmental stage of the child and the particulars of their environment. In general, children may require extra support from families and clinicians for feelings of guilt and abandonment during the initial stages of grieving as they learn not only to accept the immediate reality of loss but also the longer-term implications of the loss on their family and community. In addition, they can experience loneliness when caregivers withhold information in an attempt to protect them from the distressing details of the parent’s condition or when the surviving parent hides his or her emotions in an attempt to protect, but the child unfortunately ends up grieving alone. In the later stages of grieving, children will begin to reinvest in new relationships and return to developmentally appropriate activities; however, families should be alert for the return of pain and grief as children go through important events in their lives.Due to the complex interplay of medical, developmental, and social factors in parental separation, intervention requires an individualized approach. However, certain principles will be helpful in a broad range of scenarios.First, children have great capacity for resilience. A strong system of support should be encouraged that includes parents, other family members, peers, and professionals. Programs of varying intensities and lengths exist, including parent-child counseling, support groups, camps, writing activities, group-based interventions, and interactive online modules. Specific programs to address divorce, death, and deployment have been developed to shepherd families through the distinct adjustments that each type of separation can require. Military bases offer a robust set of resources for families living nearby, although in the case of reservists (ie, National Guard), it is possible that a family could live far from a military community and see more benefit from web-based resources. In addition, schools can be valuable partners in providing support and assessment.Second, separation from a parent may be the most traumatic and life-changing event that has ever happened to a child. Parents should be counseled to prioritize compassion and transparency because children need to sense that their caregivers are trustworthy and that their world will retain a semblance of order. Children as young as preschool should be given honest and appropriate information. Caregivers should provide children with information about how changes in their family will affect their day-to-day lives; children should be invited to share their feelings and have their questions patiently answered. Difficult concepts such as death, divorce, or an impending deployment should be explained in developmentally appropriate terms because children will attempt to fill in gaps in knowledge by themselves if information is withheld; often their imagined narrative can perpetuate a fear of further abandonment or self-blame. If parents feel ill-equipped, health-care providers, school staff, or religious leaders can assist in facilitating these conversations.Such honest discussions can be particularly valuable when there is an opportunity for gentle, developmentally appropriate end-of-life information to be given to a child before the death of a parent. Such conversations, in conjunction with opportunities to be physically present with the loved one, can allow the dying parent to play an important role of comforting the child in his or her grief.Third, children should be provided with as much consistency as possible in the midst of a changing environment. Children from infants to adolescents will benefit from maintenance of a consistent schedule, reliable demonstrations of affection, good 2-way communication, and regular quality time with their caregiver. Children may test behavioral boundaries with a different or newly single caregiver; nonetheless, discipline techniques should remain clear and consistent.Finally, parents and caregivers should also consider their personal self-care, particularly with respect to mental health. In the case of divorce, a child’s successful adjustment requires minimizing exposure to conflict and prioritizing cooperative parenting. For bereaved children, depression in surviving parents is a strong predictor of behavior disturbance in preschoolers. Regarding deployment, the challenge of separation is often exacerbated by injuries such as posttraumatic stress disorder and traumatic brain injury, the “invisible wounds” that expose family members to the secondary trauma of war.Separation from parents is a distressing but common occurrence for children in America and throughout the world. Pediatricians are strategically positioned to identify children experiencing parental separation and should be prepared to offer effective education and resources to ensure optimal adjustment to the changes taking place in the life of a family.COMMENT: Assisting a patient and family with the grief and suffering associated with separations may be one of the most rewarding journeys that we embark on as pediatric health-care providers. However, patients and families may not always think to inform us of these experiences or may be initially reluctant to share this information. Hence, it is critical for health-care providers to take the initiative to ask at each visit about family stressors and separations. Although limited time during encounters is always an issue, it is inevitably time well spent in these circumstances. This may be one of our most important roles as child advocates and understanding the dynamics of the families that we serve. Using our skills to listen carefully and to be fully present enables us to provide guidance, support, and resources that will strengthen the longitudinal relationship that we value in our role as healers while simultaneously improving the quality of the lives of our patients and their emotional health.

papers.title: Life Disruption, Independence, Satisfaction, and the Consideration of Moving
papers.abstract: Among a sample of noninstitutionalized elderly, 60% had thought of moving from their present residences. The consideration of moving was moderately associated with the occurrence of major life disruptions and strongly associated with a low level of personal independence and reduced housing and neighborhood satisfaction. Housing and household characteristics generally were not related to the consideration of moving. A causal model is proposed, with major life disruptions viewed as causing a reduction in the level of personal independence, which, in turn, lowers satisfaction and leads to the consideration of moving.

papers.title: Continuity of Learning: adding funds of knowledge from the home environment
papers.abstract: In comparison to previous generations, families these days are leading increasingly complex lives. Children often have a diversity of experiences from various learning communities before they begin school. For example, they may have been involved in one or more early childhood settings before moving on to school, where they join the new community of the school; and they have the of the home community, which may or may not involve an extended family. They may be involved in cultural, sporting, artistic, and/or spiritual communities. A child may be involved in many communities each week, or may a number of different communities over a period of time. This can be referred to as the multidimensionality of student experience (Gonzalez, Moll, & Amanti, 2005, p. 6). Some of these communities may be very similar to each other--for example, involvement in a spiritual community may in many ways require of activities similar to those practised at home. Some communities may be very disparate; for example, a swimming lesson may operate very differently from a play group and have a different set of expectations and modes of participation. The constant factor, however, is the mediating one of the family. This article explores the families have of their child and the importance for teachers, families, and the child of sharing this knowledge. Funds of In their book Funds of Knowledge Norma Gonzales, Luis Moll, and Cathy Amanti define of knowledge as being based on a simple premise: People are competent, they have knowledge, and their life experiences have given them that knowledge (2005, p. ix). Gonzales et al. focus on developing reciprocal relationships with families, in part to identify the knowledge, skills, and experiences of families that could be shared with the to enhance classroom practice and students' learning: [a] funds of approach facilitates a systematic and powerful way to represent communities in terms of resources, the wherewithal they possess, and how to harness these resources for classroom teachers (p. x). As well as viewing a family's skills and as resources the teacher can tap into, it is also possible to see the family as a mediating factor in terms of the child's interactions with the various learning communities the child is involved in (as shown in Figure 1). This view highlights the necessity of developing reciprocal and responsive relationships between the family and the centre or classroom. In this framework the family can be seen as a pivotal point and constant frame of reference for the child. At any one time a child is a participant in many communities, not just one. It is the family, as the mediating factor, that has the of the child's of these things. Communities of practice When we look more closely at the child's of, and between, these communities, a useful concept is Etienne Wenger's (1998) definition of a community of practice as a living context that can give newcomers access to competence and also invite a personal of engagement by which to incorporate that competence into an identity of (p. 214). Children come to an early childhood centre or school with varying experiences of participation. Each of the communities they have been a part of may have functioned in entirely different ways, with a multitude of different foci. How they have approached these different settings and how their sense of belonging, engagement, and participation has developed are important indicators for a teacher in deciding how to scaffold and bridge a child's entry into, and learning within, any community of learning. Once again, it is often the family that holds this information. Reciprocal relationships In their exploration of funds of Gonzales et al. papers.title: Besonderheiten moderner Rehabilitation beim betagten Menschen
papers.abstract: Zusammenfassung. Aufgrund der demografischen Entwicklung gewinnt die Rehabilitation Betagter an Bedeutung. Im Vergleich zum jüngeren Patienten sind beim betagten Patienten die Autonomie und die Handlungsfähigkeit in Alltagssituationen meist rascher bedroht, die soziale Partizipation fragiler, und somit die Gefahr der Vereinsamung prinzipiell grösser. Die Kommunikation mit dem Umfeld spielt eine grössere Rolle. Das Risiko für Komplikationen ist hoch; andererseits äussern betagte Patienten in der Regel weniger Angst vor dem Tod als vor einem völligen Verlust der Selbständigkeit und davor, ihren Angehörigen «zur Last zu fallen». Auch betagte Patienten profitieren von organspezifischen Rehabilitationsmassnahmen auf dem Niveau der Alltagsfunktionalität und sozialen Partizipation, wie dies exemplarisch für die Neurorehabilitation nach Schlagfanfall gezeigt wurde. Die geriatrische Rehabilitation fokussiert spezifisch auf die Bedürfnisse Betagter, die durch Multimorbidität, Vulnerabilität oder Gebrechlichkeit (Frailty) charakterisiert sind. Sie ist als interprofessioneller Prozess aufgebaut, der polymodal körperliche, psychische und soziale Aspekte systematisch erfasst und mit dem Patienten und seinem Umfeld ein individuell adaptiertes Ziel erarbeitet. Zentral sind die Aspekte Mobilität, Selbsthilfefähigkeit, Ernährung, Kognition, Stimmung, Kontinenz und soziale Situation. Ein Tragpfeiler ist dabei eine altersadaptierte, proteinreiche Ernährung. Ärztlicherseits wird es – gerade bei der Rehabilitation Betagter – hilfreich sein, die Kompetenzen aus verschiedenen Fachrichtungen synergistisch zu nutzen. Unter der Vorstellung einer optimalen Betreuung und Beratung gerade in den Kompetenzfeldern Mobilität, Kognition und Ernährung kann eine Co-Betreuung ein zukunftsfähiges Modell sein. Im Hinblick auf die rehabilitative Prognose dürfte «Alter» im Sinne der Anzahl bisheriger Lebensjahre eine überschätzte Prognosevariable sein. «Höheres Alter» kann hingegen als Surrogatmarker für Komorbiditäten gelten, die mit zunehmendem Lebensalter an Häufigkeit zunehmen. Unter diesen Gesichtspunkten ist es unbedingt zu vermeiden, dass betagte Patienten rein auf Grund ihrer bereits verbrachten Lebensjahre weniger häufig als Jüngere die Chance einer rehabilitativen Behandlung erhalten.

papers.title: Ações de cuidado nas relações intrageracionais em crianças em acolhimento institucional
papers.abstract:
